fields.title: About this Project
fields.content:
What It Asks:

  • What if we could collect all the statements, from all fields of knowledge, that describe what “it” is?
  • What if we could pull them out of their original sources and contexts, and play with them, remix them, in new ways?
  • What new meanings could emerge?
  • What could we do, collaboratively, with such a collection, and with such an approach to our systems and sources of knowledge?

What It Is:

  • It is an initial exploration of these questions, not a final answer.
  • It is a playground and a tool.
  • It is a suggestion that we can remix knowledge, just as we can remix other media.
  • It is an experiment in object-oriented thought, the concept that thoughts are objects that can be appropriated, manipulated, and adapted to the needs of the moment.
  • It is an experimental space for the exploration of quantum semantics, the belief that we can break down large, heavy thought-objects (source texts) into small, discrete, lightweight thought-objects (statements), and that the powerful semantic energies unleashed by this process can be channeled into new meanings.
  • It is a practice of radical recombinance, the collection and remixing of radicals (i.e. "roots") into new thought-objects, guided by intuition, intent, and improvisation (as opposed to systematic rationality).
  • It is a suggestion of a new process and a playground for a new method (as opposed to a fixed, final product).
  • It is just an initial step.

Ultimately, "What It Is" depends on how you want to use it, what you imagine it could be.
We invite you to help us discover that, by:

  • Playing with the site, and creating your own collection of statements.
  • Adding a statement or source text.
  • Downloading the statements for your own use.
  • Sending suggestions, questions, or other feedback to "adam" AT "therealadamgood.com"
  • Joining us on Facebook

"What It Is" was conceived by Adam Good, and built by Chris Davis, Tim Cripps, James Stevenson, and Chuck Harmston.

It Is based an open-source cycle of use and re-use. These statements are their own agents now. This system is a seed for more systems. Go crazy. Just let us know what cool stuff you're doing with them.

fields.title: Participate
fields.content:
“What It Is” is an open-source work in progress, an evolving tool.
We’d like you to use it, and to help us expand it.

We invite you to download the statements collected here for your own use.

We’d also appreciate any suggestions you have about how we can expand this project, ways that you’d like to help, or feedback on how you are using the statements.

Please email comments, suggestions, or inquiries to "adam" AT "therealadamgood.com."

You can also add a statement or source to the database, while you’re here.
Or join us on Facebook.

Thanks for playing.
The "What It Is" Team

fields.title: Synopsis for Transmediale Submission
fields.content:
Comment, if you'd like, below.

“What It Is” is a tool for collecting statements from all fields of knowledge, that describe what “it” is, and for remixing them into new knowledge. All disciplines use the phrase “it is” to describe and construct the concepts and objects within their domains. This project asks the question: what if we took all those descriptions, freed them from their original contexts, collected them in one database, and allowed people to reuse them for their own purposes? We believe that doing this will create new possibilities for what “it” could be, and will allow new realities to emerge.

“What It Is” proposes a new model for interacting with, and creating, knowledge, a model based on breaking down all texts into small, lightweight objects (i.e., statements) that can be explored and reused without the constraints of academic disciplines. This model aims to make knowledge more flexible, adaptive, recombinant, improvisatory, and collaborative. Accordingly, we leverage the open web technologies (HTML 5, Django) and practices that are essential to creating this transformation.

We see “What It Is” as the first step towards a vast, open-source “Database of Descriptions” that breaks down ALL knowledge into small, discrete components for perpetual reuse. We invite the artistic, developer, and scientific communities to help us build this system and create applications that expand its capabilities. We invite you to help us discover what “it” is and, more importantly, to create what “it” could be.
